title: 112_s1456
content: The Act may be cited as the "Disaster Tax Act of 2011" and pertains to losses attributable to federally declared disasters. The Disaster Tax Act of 2011 amends the Internal Revenue Code to waive the adjusted gross income limitation and increase the standard deduction for disaster casualty losses. It also increases the limitation on individual loss per casualty for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. The Disaster Tax Act of 2011 amends the Internal Revenue Code to waive the adjusted gross income limitation and increase the standard deduction for disaster casualty losses. It also increases the limitation on individual loss per casualty for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. A technical amendment inserts "major" after "means any" in section 165(h)(3)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 3. EXPENSING OF QUALIFIED DISASTER EXPENSES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to change the date for expensing qualified disaster expenses. Effective for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2010, for disasters declared after that date. SEC. 4. NET OPERATING LOSSES ATTRIBUTABLE TO FEDERALLY DECLARED DISASTERS. SEC. 4 amends the Internal Revenue Code to adjust net operating losses related to federally declared disasters. It eliminates an exclusion and changes the effective date for losses arising after December 31, 2010. SEC. 6 amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase expensing for qualified disaster assistance property, effective for disasters occurring after December 31, 2010. SEC. 6 increases expensing for qualified disaster assistance property under the Internal Revenue Code, effective for disasters after December 31, 2010. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow qualified disaster contributions up to 80 percent of the taxpayer's contribution base, with any excess eligible for carryover. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows qualified disaster contributions exceeding the limitation to be treated as charitable contributions over 5 succeeding years. Coordination with other subparagraphs is required, and contributions described in clause (i) are not treated as described in subparagraphs (A). Qualified disaster contributions are charitable contributions made in cash after the enactment of a specific paragraph to organizations aiding in relief efforts for federally declared disasters. Qualified disaster contributions are charitable contributions made in cash to organizations aiding in relief efforts for federally declared disasters, excluding contributions for donor advised funds. Taxpayers must obtain a written acknowledgment from the organization confirming the use of the contribution for the intended purpose. Qualified disaster contributions are allowed up to 20 percent of taxable income over the amount of charitable contributions allowed under subparagraph (A), with a carryover provision for excess contributions. The provision allows for excess contributions to be carried over as charitable contributions for up to 5 years. Qualified disaster contributions are defined separately, and there are substantiation requirements for them. The provision allows excess contributions to be carried over as charitable contributions for up to 5 years. Qualified disaster contributions require a written acknowledgment from the organization stating the purpose of the contribution. Amendments are made to sections 170(b)(2) of the Code to include additional requirements. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 8. INCREASE IN NEW MARKETS TAX CREDIT FOR INVESTMENTS IN COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ENTITIES SERVING DISASTER AREAS. SEC. 8. INCREASE IN NEW MARKETS TAX CREDIT FOR INVESTMENTS IN COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ENTITIES SERVING DISASTER AREAS. Subsection (f) of section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the limitation by $250,000,000 for qualified community development entities to make investments in federally declared disaster areas. The Secretary will allocate funds to qualified community development entities with a track record of assisting businesses or communities in federally declared disaster areas. The term 'federally declared disaster area' refers to an area eligible for assistance under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act applies to federally declared disasters. The amendments made by this section will be effective for calendar years after 2010.
